message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, especially the involvement of the base of the left big toe, suggest gout. Therefore, arthrocentesis of the involved joints is most likely to show monosodium urate crystals.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest gout, which is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints. Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are associated with pseudogout and calcium phosphate crystals are associated with osteoarthritis. Gram-positive cocci in clusters are associated with septic arthritis, but the patient does not have fever or leukocytosis suggestive of bacterial infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical symptoms and history suggest gout, which is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints. The high leukocyte count and elevated creatinine indicate a possible kidney problem, which can exacerbate gout. Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are associated with pseudogout, but the symptoms and history do not suggest this diagnosis. Calcium phosphate crystals are associated with osteoarthritis, not acute joint swelling. Gram-positive cocci in clusters would suggest a bacterial infection, but this is less likely given the history and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest gout, which is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joint spaces leading to inflammation. Arthrocentesis in this case is most likely to show monosodium urate crystals, confirming the diagnosis of gout. Calcium pyrophosphate crystals would suggest pseudogout, which typically involves large joints such as the knee. Calcium phosphate crystals are not typically associated with joint inflammation. Gram-positive cocci in clusters would suggest a bacterial infection, which is not likely the cause of the patient’s symptoms in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and lab values suggest gout, which is characterized by the presence of monosodium urate crystals in the affected joint. Calcium pyrophosphate crystals and calcium phosphate crystals are associated with pseudogout. Gram-positive cocci in clusters may indicate a bacterial infection, but the other symptoms do not suggest this as the likely cause of the joint pain and swelling.

We refer to UpToDate for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest gout, which is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints. Arthrocentesis is likely to show these crystals. Calcium pyrophosphate crystals cause pseudogout, which presents with similar symptoms but is less likely in this patient with chronic myelogenous leukemia. Calcium phosphate crystals can cause a different type of arthritis, and gram-positive cocci in clusters would suggest a bacterial infection, which is less likely in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of acute gouty arthritis, given his history of leukemia and recent chemotherapy. Arthrocentesis of the involved joints is likely to show monosodium urate crystals, which are the hallmark of gout. Calcium pyrophosphate crystals typically cause pseudogout, which much less commonly affects the knee joint, while calcium phosphate crystals are associated with osteoarthritis. Gram-positive cocci in clusters suggest a bacterial infection, which is not likely in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and medical history suggest gout, which is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints. The laboratory findings do not indicate any other crystal deposition or infection. Therefore, arthrocentesis is most likely to show monosodium urate crystals.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest gout, which is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints. Arthrocentesis would confirm the presence of these crystals in the joint fluid. Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are associated with pseudogout, which presents differently. Calcium phosphate crystals are associated with other conditions such as osteoarthritis and hyperparathyroidism. Gram-positive cocci in clusters would suggest a bacterial infection, which is not the most likely cause in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has inflammation and swelling in both knees and the base of his left big toe suggesting gout. The laboratory values support this diagnosis as well since the serum uric acid level is not provided. Arthrocentesis is likely to show monosodium urate crystals, which are typically found in cases of gout. The other options (B,C, and D) are associated with different types of arthritis and are less likely based on the presentation of the patient.
